post-details.content: You can render a Nuxt page by using the `` component. You have to put it in the `app.vue` file: ```html ``` It will be able to inspect the current path and render the corresponding page in your **pages** folder.

post-details.title: Layout for the App
post-details.content:
You can set up a layout to be shared between the pages of your app.

Use the `<NuxtLayout>` component in the **app.vue** file:
```html
<template>
  <NuxtLayout>
    <NuxtPage />
  <NuxtLayout>
</template>
```

Then it will find the component in **layouts/default.vue** and render that as the layout.

post-details.title: Getting the Current Path
post-details.content:
Use `useRoute` to get the path of the current page.
```js
const route = useRoute()
console.log(route.path)
```

post-details.title: Dynamic Page Transition
Fetch data with useFetch
post-details.content:
You can fetch data from the server directly in the component.

The `useFetch` composable will make sure the same data don't have to be refetched again on the client side.
```js
const { data } = await useFetch('/api/path')
```

post-details.title: Fetch data with custom logic
The NuxtLink Component
post-details.content:
Use `<NuxtLink>` to create a link between two pages as in a single-page app.
```html
<NuxtLink to="/path">
  Click Here
</NuxtLink>
```

This navigation will take place entirely on the client side.

post-details.title: Route Validation
Getting Route Params
post-details.content:
The params of the route can be accessed through the `useRoute` composable.
```js
const category = useRoute().params.category
```

post-details.title: The useState Composable
post-details.content:
You can init a state on the server side using `useState`.

Provide a functon that returns the initial value for the state:
```js
const state = useState(() => 'sample value')
```

Then this state will be available on the client side.

Render part of the page only on the client
post-details.content:
You can opt out of Server-Side Rendering on the component level. Just wrap the `` component around the part of template that you want to render client-side only. ```html

This will get rendered only on the client side.

 ``` The `fallback-tag` and `fallback` attributes are used as placeholder while the content is being rendered.

post-details.title: Preload Images
post-details.content:
Use the `preload` attribute on `<NuxtImg>` to load images that you need to display immediately.
```html
<template>
  <NuxtImg
    preload
    src='/cat.png'      
  />
</template>
```
